revision.comment: Per [[MOS:LAYOUTEL]]
revision.text:
The '''Afghan Women's Network''' (AWN) is a [[non-governmental organization]] (NGO) which was created in 1996 by [[Afghanistan|Afghan]] women following the [[Fourth World Conference on Women|World Conference on Women]] in [[Beijing]] and works to "empower women and ensure their equal participation in Afghan society."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afghanwomennetwork.af/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110815122257/http://www.afghanwomennetwork.af/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2011-08-15 |title=Web site of The Afghan Women's Network |publisher=Afghanwomennetwork.af |date= |accessdate=2013-06-06 }}</ref>
== About ==
The AWN sustains the vision of an Afghanistan in which women & men live in a justice and discrimination free society. AWN's axis of focus are:<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.awn-af.net/index.php/cms/more/177|title=Afghan Women's Network.|website=www.awn-af.net|language=en|access-date=2017-07-16}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=https://www.insightonconflict.org/conflicts/afghanistan/peacebuilding-organisations/afghan-womens-network-awn/|title=Insight on Conflict|last=|first=|date=|work=Insight on Conflict|access-date=2017-07-26|language=en}}</ref> * Women, peace and security * Women's political participation and leadership * Women's social and legal protection
The AWN acts as a foundation supporting other [[women's rights]]-oriented NGO in Afghanistan and Pakistan. The AWN receives funding from donor agencies such as the [[French Embassy]], [[ActionAid]], [[UNHCR]], and Roland Berger Foundation. It operates from Kabul, Heart, Balkh, Kandahar, Bamyan, Paktia, Nangarhar, and Kunduz, ... It has more than 3,500 individual members (exclusively women) and 125 women's organizations with memberships<ref name=":02">{{Cite web|url=http://www.awn-af.net/index.php/cms/content/68|title=AWN History|last=|first=|date=|website=www.awn-af.net|language=en|access-date=2017-07-16}}</ref>.
Executive board members have included [[Manizha Wafeq]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.kardan.edu.af/FortyUnderForty/Manizha-Wafeq|title=Kardan University|website=www.kardan.edu.af|access-date=2016-12-23}}</ref> and the current executive director is Hassina Safi.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url = https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2015/mar/09/international-womens-day-fund-womens-role-peace|title = Time To Fund Women's Role in the Cause of Peace|last = Filippini|first = Simone|date = 9 March 2015|work = The Guardian|access-date = 9 September 2015|via = }}</ref>
== History == The Afghan Women's Network was established in 1995. Women who had participated in the United Nation Fourth World Conference on Women in Beijing, China decided that they wanted to create a network for Afghan women<ref name=":4" />.
In 2013, The AWN played an active role in the curation of the exhibit ''Women Between Peace and War: Afghanistan'' by Leslie Thomas from ArtWORKS Projects for Human Rights.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://asiasociety.org/blog/asia/photosinterview-arresting-images-capture-afghan-women-between-peace-and-war|title=Photos/Interview: Arresting Images Capture Afghan Women 'Between Peace and War'|website=Asiasociety.org|date=30 September 2013|author=James Kochien|accessdate=10 November 2017}}</ref>
In March 2014, the AWN launched the ''Afghan Women Vision 2024'', the ONG's official newspaper supported by the [[Heinrich Boell Foundation]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.boell.de/en/2014/03/10/afghan-women-vision-2024|title=Afghan Women Vision 2024|website=Boell.de|date=10 March 2014|accessdate=10 November 2017}}</ref> In 2014, the ONG stated that 150 [[honor killing]]s affected Afghan women each year.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/05/04/world/asia/in-spite-of-the-law-afghan-honor-killings-of-women-continue.html|title=In Spite of the Law, Afghan ‘Honor Killings’ of Women Continue|website=Nytimes.com|date=3 May 2014|author=Rod Nordland|accessdate=10 November 2017}}</ref> Upon the progressive withdrawal of US troops from Afghanistan, the AWN brought its focus on maintaining the women's rights benefits gained during the presence of the US troops.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.csmonitor.com/World/Progress-Watch/2015/0106/Afghanistan-Women-s-rights-make-big-gains|title=Afghanistan: Women's rights make big gains|website=Csmonitor.com|date=6 January 2015|author=Anne Steele|accessdate=10 November 2017}}</ref>
In February 2015, the AWN took part to the marches asking the president [[Ashraf Ghani]] to respect his word and name 4 women ministries in his government for fair gender representation.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2015/feb/03/afghan-women-protest-absence-female-ministers-new-cabinet|title=Afghan women protest at absence of female ministers in new cabinet|website=Theguardian.com|date=3 February 2015|author=Sune Engel Rasmussen |accessdate=10 November 2017}}</ref> In 2016, the ONG spoke out about the revival of public executions of women in Afghanistan following the new peak of influence from the [[Taliban]]s.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://broadly.vice.com/en_us/article/bmw97w/the-taliban-is-publicly-executing-women-again|title=The Taliban Is Publicly Executing Women Again|website=Vice.com|date=16 May 2016|author=Mari Shibata|accessdate=10 November 2017}}</ref>
== Governance == ;Board of Directors<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.awn-af.net/index.php/cms/content/1248|title=AWN Board of Directors|last=|first=|date=|website=www.awn-af.net|language=en|access-date=2017-07-16}}</ref>: * February 2016 - February 2018: Shahla Fari, Zarqa Yaftali, Nooria Safi, Samira Hamidi, Roshan Sirran, Mary Akrami, Shafiqa Habibi * February 2014 - February 2016: Mary Akrami, Gul Makai Siawash, Maryam Rahmani, Shahla Farid, Arezoo Qanih, Samira Hamidi, Zarqa Yaftali * February 2012 - February 2014: Nasima Omari, HasFeina Safi, Mahbooba Sij, Shinkaj Karokhail, Lida Nadery Hedayat, Manizha Wafiq, Ruqia Azizi * February 2010 - February 2012: Homa Alizoi, Hazina Safi, Najila Ayoobi, Shahla Farid, Selay Ghafar
;Management Team<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.awn-af.net/index.php/cms/content/73|title=AWN Management Team|last=|first=|date=|website=www.awn-af.net|language=en|access-date=2017-07-16}}</ref>: * Executive Director: Mrs. Hassina Safi * Admin/HR Manager: Ms. Wazhma Popal * Networking Manager: Mrs. Roshna Mashal * Advocacy/Law Manager: Mrs. Robina Hamdard
== See also == *[[Jamila Afghani]] *[[Farida Azizi]] *[[Taliban treatment of women]]
==Reference List== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.awn-af.net/ Official website]
[[Category:Women's organisations based in Afghanistan]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1996]] [[Category:1996 establishments in Afghanistan]]
{{-}} {{Women's-History-stub}} {{Afghanistan-org-stub}}

revision.comment: members of the USAF are "airmen" (regardless of gender), not "soldiers"
revision.text:
{{Unreferenced stub|date=December 2009}} {{Politics of Iceland}} The '''Agreed Minute''' was a statute governing the nature of the [[United States of America|U.S.]] [[military]] presence in [[Iceland]] from 1994 to 2006.
In 1951 American troops returned to Iceland to form an [[Iceland Defense Force]]. As Iceland has had no standing [[Military of Iceland|military]] of its own since [[World War II]], while [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] threat heightened and thus requiring standing defences.
After the [[Cold War]] ended, U.S. forces were constrained by the financial situation and were yearning to leave Iceland. While Icelandic politicians disagreed with such a move. Hence the Agreed Minute, signed in 1994 where both parties compromised and came to an understanding.
The Agreed Minute was last renegotiated in 2001. At the time, the [[United States Air Force|U.S. Air Force]] committed itself to maintaining four to six [[interceptors]] at the [[Naval Air Station Keflavik|Keflavík]] base, supported by a helicopter rescue squad. The Air Force, in order to cut costs, announced plans to remove the four remaining jets in 2003. The removal was then delayed to address Icelandic demands for continued presence of the jets. After an unfruitful series of negotiations and two reshufflings of the Icelandic government the issue lay dormant until early 2006 when the U.S. Air Force issued an official statement that withdrawal of the aircraft was already being prepared. U.S. officials have since then argued that Iceland is in no need of U.S. military presence and the last remaining airmen left Iceland during September 2006.
[[Category:Military of Iceland]] [[Category:Treaties of Iceland]] [[Category:Treaties of the United States]] [[Category:Treaties concluded in 1994]] [[Category:Iceland–United States relations]]
{{Iceland-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox spaceflight | name = BeeSat-1 | image = BeeSat-FM Post-Acceptance-Test-Checkout 2008-09.JPG | image_caption = BeeSat-1 before launch | mission_type = Technology | operator = [[Technical University of Berlin|TUB]] | website = {{url|http://www.raumfahrttechnik.tu-berlin.de/beesat/v-menue2/project_overview/}} | COSPAR_ID = 2009-051C | SATCAT = 35933 | mission_duration = 12 months (planned)
15+ months (achieved) | spacecraft_type = 1U [[CubeSat]] | manufacturer = | dry_mass = | launch_mass = {{convert|1|kg}} | power = | launch_date = {{start-date|23 September 2009, 06:21|timezone=yes}} UTC | launch_rocket = [[Polar Satellite Launch Vehicle|PSLV-CA]] C14 | launch_site = [[Satish Dhawan Space Centre|Satish Dhawan]] [[Satish Dhawan Space Centre First Launch Pad|FLP]] | launch_contractor = [[Indian Space Research Organisation|ISRO]] | last_contact = | decay_date = | orbit_epoch = 21 January 2014, 05:49:02 UTC{{cite web|url=http://www.n2yo.com/satellite/?s=35933|title=BEESAT Satellite details 2009-051C NORAD 35933|work=N2YO|date=21 January 2014|accessdate=21 January 2014}} | orbit_reference = [[geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[Sun-synchronous orbit|Sun-synchronous]] | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|713|km|mi}} | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|723|km|mi}} | orbit_inclination = 98.36 degrees | orbit_period = 99.01 minutes | apsis = gee }} '''BeeSat-1''' or '''Berlin Experimental and Educational Satellite 1''', is a [[Germany|German]] [[satellite]] operated by the [[Technical University of Berlin]]. The spacecraft is a single unit [[CubeSat]], which was designed to test systems intended for use on future spacecraft, including a new design of [[reaction wheel]].{{cite web |title=BEESAT-1 |url=http://www.raumfahrttechnik.tu-berlin.de/beesat/v-menue2/beesat-1/ |publisher=TUB |accessdate=6 January 2011 |date=25 May 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110218222803/http://www.raumfahrttechnik.tu-berlin.de/beesat/v-menue2/beesat-1 |archivedate=18 February 2011 |df= }}{{cite web|title=BeeSat-1 (Berlin Experimental Educational Satellite-1) |url=http://events.eoportal.org/get_announce.php?an_id=11635 |work=eoPortal Directory |publisher=eoPortal |accessdate=6 January 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726032851/http://events.eoportal.org/get_announce.php?an_id=11635 |archivedate=26 July 2011 |df= }} It has also been used for [[amateur radio]], and is equipped with a small camera. BeeSat-1 was launched by a [[Polar Satellite Launch Vehicle]], serial number C14, flying in the Core Alone, or PSLV-CA, configuration.{{cite web|last=Wade|first=Mark|title=PSLV CA|url=http://www.astronautix.com/lvs/pslvca.htm|work=Encyclopedia Astronautica|accessdate=6 January 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111011075653/http://astronautix.com/lvs/pslvca.htm|archivedate=11 October 2011|df=}} The launch took place from the [[Satish Dhawan Space Centre First Launch Pad|First Launch Pad]] at the [[Satish Dhawan Space Centre]], at 06:21 UTC on 23 September 2009.{{cite web|last=McDowell|first=Jonathan|title=Launch Log|url=http://www.planet4589.org/space/log/launchlog.txt|work=Jonathan's Space Page|accessdate=6 January 2011}} BeeSat-1 was a secondary payload aboard the rocket, which deployed the [[Oceansat-2]] satellite. Five other secondary payloads were flown aboard the rocket; [[SwissCube-1]], [[UWE-2]], [[ITU-pSat1]], [[Rubin 9.1]] and [[Rubin 9.2]].{{cite web|last=Krebs|first=Gunter|title=BeeSat|url=http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/beesat.htm|work=Gunter's Space Page|accessdate=6 January 2011}}{{cite web|last=Krebs|first=Gunter|title=Rubin 9|url=http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/rubin-9-ais.htm|work=Gunter's Space Page|accessdate=6 January 2011}} BeeSat-1 is operating in a [[sun synchronous orbit]] with an [[Apsis|apogee]] of {{convert|723|km}}, a [[Apsis|perigee]] of {{convert|714|km}} and 98.4 degrees of [[inclination]] to the [[equator]]. It has an [[orbital period]] of 99.16 minutes.{{cite web|last=McDowell|first=Jonathan|title=Satellite Catalog|url=http://www.planet4589.org/space/log/satcat.txt|work=Jonathan's Space Page|accessdate=6 January 2011}} BeeSat-1 was designed to operate for at least twelve months, and {{As of|2011|1|lc=y}} it is still operational.{{cite web|title=BEESAT|url=http://www.amsat.org/amsat-new/satellites/satInfo.php?satID=129|publisher=AMSAT|accessdate=6 January 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110303221829/http://www.amsat.org/amsat-new/satellites/satInfo.php?satID=129|archivedate=3 March 2011|df=}} ==See also== {{Portal|Spaceflight}} * [[2009 in spaceflight]] * [[List of CubeSats]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Orbital launches in 2009}} {{Use British English|date=January 2014}} [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 2009]] [[Category:CubeSats]] [[Category:Student satellites]] [[Category:Satellites of Germany]] {{Germany-spacecraft-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2018}} {|{{Infobox ship begin |display title=ital}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image=Berlin Nakroma, Dili, 2018 (01).jpg |Ship caption=''Berlin Nakroma'' in [[Dili]], October 2018 }} {{Infobox ship career |Hide header= |Ship name= {{ubl|''Nakroma'' (2007–2008)|''Berlin Nakroma'' (2008–)}} |Ship operator=[[Government of East Timor]] |Ship registry= [[Jakarta]], {{flag|Indonesia}} |Ship ordered= |Ship awarded= |Ship builder= [[PT PAL|PAL Indonesia]], Surabaya |Ship yard number= |Ship laid down= |Ship launched= |Ship sponsor= |Ship christened= |Ship acquired= 2007 |Ship status= In service |Ship completed= |Ship maiden voyage= |Ship out of service= |Ship identification=*{{IMO Number|9335472}} *{{MMSI Number|525015158}} *[[Maritime call sign|Callsign]]: 4WABN |Ship notes= }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header = |Header caption = |Ship tonnage = *{{GT|1,134}} <!--*{{NetT|xxxx}}--> *{{DWT|262}} |Ship displacement = |Ship length = {{convert|47.25|m|abbr=on}} |Ship beam = {{convert|12|m|abbr=on}} |Ship height = |Ship draught = |Ship power = |Ship propulsion = |Ship speed = |Ship capacity = {{ubl|300 passengers|{{DWT|110|metric}} cargo}} |Ship crew = |Ship decks = |Ship notes = }} |}
'''''Berlin Nakroma''''' is a [[roll-on/roll-off]] passenger and cargo [[ferry]] owned and operated by the [[Government of East Timor]] since 2007. A gift to East Timor from the [[Federal Republic of Germany]], she links [[Dili]], capital city of East Timor, with [[Pante Macassar]] in the East Timorese [[exclave]] of [[Oecusse]], and with [[Atauro Island]].
==Concept and construction== [[File:Berlin Nakroma.JPG|thumb|left|''Nakroma'' in September 2007|alt=Nakroma in September 2007]] The Democratic Republic of East Timor is made up of three main parts, being the eastern half of [[Timor]], the exclave of Oecusse adjacent to the northwestern coast of Timor, and the island of Atauro. Passport-free transport between these three locations is possible only by sea.<ref name=giz>{{cite web |title=German Cooperation in Timor-Leste: Financial Cooperation in the Martime [sic] Transport Sector |url=https://www.giz.de/en/downloads/giz2013-en-development-cooperation-timor-leste-germany.pdf |website=Deutsche Gesellschaft für Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ) |accessdate=14 November 2018 |date=February 2013}}</ref>
In 2002, the German [[Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development]] (BMZ) commissioned a cooperation project to improve East Timorese living conditions by establishing a regular maritime passenger and goods transport connection between the three locations.<ref name="giz"/>
From 2003 to 2006, a passenger ferry was chartered to operate such a connection. During that period, around 3,400 passengers used the service each month. In February 2007, a new ferry commissioned by the BMZ and financed by [[KfW|KfW Development Bank]], the ''Nakroma'', was officially handed over to the East Timorese government to assume the operation of the service.<ref name="giz"/><ref name="gffo">{{cite web |title=Timor-Leste |url=https://www.auswaertiges-amt.de/en/aussenpolitik/laenderinformationen/timorleste-node/timorleste/233668 |website=German Federal Foreign Office |accessdate=14 November 2018 |date=October 2015}}</ref><ref name="bmz">{{cite web |title=Eine Fähre für Timor-Leste |trans-title=A Ferry for East Timor |url=http://www.bmz.de/de/was_wir_machen/laender_regionen/asien/timor_leste/timor_leste_transport.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120528093043/http://www.bmz.de/de/was_wir_machen/laender_regionen/asien/timor_leste/timor_leste_transport.html |website=Bundesministerium für wirtschaftliche Zusammenarbeit und Entwicklung [Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development] |archive-date=28 May 2012 |accessdate=14 November 2018 |lang=de }}</ref>
The donated ferry was built in [[Surabaya]], Indonesia, by [[PT PAL|PAL Indonesia]].<ref name="mc">{{cite web |title=9335472 BERLIN NAKROMA |url=http://maritime-connector.com/ship/berlin-nakroma-9335472/ |website=Maritime Connector |accessdate=14 November 2018}}</ref> She is a roll-on/roll-off vessel {{convert|47.25|m|abbr=on}} long, and has a beam of {{convert|12|m|abbr=on}}. Her tonnage is {{GT|1,134|disp=long}} and {{DWT|262|disp=long}}.<ref name="mt">{{cite web |title=BERLIN NAKROMA Ro-Ro/Passenger Ship |url=https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:3814423/mmsi:525015158/imo:9335472/vessel:BERLIN_NAKROMA |website=MarineTraffic.com |accessdate=14 November 2018}}</ref> She can carry up to 300 passengers (20 in first class, 149 in second class forward, and 131 in second class aft), and up to {{DWT|110|metric|disp=long}} of cargo.<ref name="bmz"/><ref name="burnet">{{cite book |last1=Burnet |first1=Ian |title=Archipelago: A Journey Across Indonesia |date=2015 |publisher=Rosenberg Publishing |location=Kenthurst, NSW |isbn=9781925078718 |chapter=Chapter 15 East Timor – Portuguese Dili|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=Pb7SCgAAQBAJ&pg=PT175&lpg=PT175&dq=berlin+nakroma&source=bl&ots=FgyUokjV1P&sig=lgWxJo1YTw9FvRSTDtH6kSKzpz0&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwin8sOE_tLeAhVLuY8KHW-PBVA4HhDoATAFegQICBAB#v=onepage&q=berlin%20nakroma&f=false |accessdate=14 November 2018}}</ref>
In recognition of the success of the cooperation project, the ferry was renamed ''Berlin Nakroma''.<ref name="bmz"/>
==Service history== ''Berlin Nakroma'' operates regular ferry services linking Dili with Pante Macassar in Oecusse, and with Atauro, using landing facilities in Dili and Oecusse that were upgraded as part of the cooperation project.<ref name="giz"/>
The vessel flies an Indonesian flag with Jakarta as her port of registry, although an East Timorese ship registry was established in 2015 and was scheduled to be up and running by 2017.<ref name="mt"/><ref name="fp 2016-09-26">{{cite web |last1=Reynolds |first1=Zoe |title=Timor-Leste sets its sights on maritime statehood |url=https://fairplay.ihs.com/commerce/article/4275546/timor-leste-sets-its-sights-maritime-statehood |website=Fairplay |accessdate=14 November 2018 |date=26 September 2016}}</ref>
In July 2017, it was announced that the German government had donated €7.5 million to the East Timor Ministry of Public Works, Transport and Communication (MOPTK), for the building of a ''Berlin Nakroma II''. East Timor would be designing the new ship, while the funds from Germany would be used to build her.<ref name="tdw 2017-07-13">{{cite news |last1=Oliveira |first1=Venidora |title=Germany donates €7.5 million for the building of Nakroma II |url=http://www.thediliweekly.com/en/news/development/14568-germany-donates-7-5-million-for-the-building-of-nakroma-ii |accessdate=14 November 2018 |work=The Dili Weekly |date=13 July 2017}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Commonscat-inline|Berlin Nakroma (ship, 2007)|Berlin Nakroma}}
[[Category:Ferries of East Timor]] [[Category:Ferries of Indonesia]] [[Category:International development]] [[Category:Ships built in Indonesia]] [[Category:2007 ships]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox television channel | name = CGTN Arabic | logofile = CGTN arabic.png | logosize = | logocaption = Logo of the channel starting 2017. | logoalt = Logo of the channel starting 2017 | launch = {{Start date and age|2009|7|25}} | closed date = | picture format = [[576i]] ([[16:9]] [[Standard-definition television|SDTV]]) | share = | share as of = | share source = | owner = [[China Global Television Network]]
(subsidiary of [[China Central Television]]) | slogan = | country = [[China]] | language = [[Arabic]] | broadcast area = Worldwide | headquarters = [[Beijing]], China | former names = CCTV-Arabic (2009–2016) | replaced names = | replaced by names = | sister names = {{ubl|[[CGTN (Channel)|CGTN]]|[[CGTN Spanish]]|[[CGTN French]]|[[CGTN Russian]]|[[CGTN Documentary]]}} | timeshift names = | website = {{URL|http://www.cgtn.com/ar.do}} | terr serv 1 = | terr chan 1 = | sat serv 1 = [[Badr-6]] (Middle East) | sat chan 1 = 11785 V / 27500 / 3/4 (SD) | sat serv 2 = [[Nilesat 201]] (Middle East) | sat chan 2 = 12015 V / 27500 / 5/6 (SD) | sat serv 3 = [[Eutelsat 9B]] (Europe) | sat chan 3 = 11996 V / 27500 / 3/4 (SD) | sat serv 4 = [[Apstar-7]] (China) | sat chan 4 = 3831 H / 15050 / 3/4 (C-Band / SD) | sat serv 5 = [[Chinasat-6B]] (China) | sat chan 5 = 4116 H / 21374 / 3/4 (C-Band / SD) | sat serv 6 = [[OSN]] {{small|(MENA)}} | sat chan 6 = Channel 461 (SD) | cable serv 1 = | cable chan 1 = | sat radio serv 1 = | sat radio chan 1 = | iptv serv 1 = [[Maroc Telecom]] (Morocco) | iptv chan 1 = Channel 107 (SD) | online serv 1 = [[CNTV|CNTV Ai Bugu]] (China) | online chan 1 = [http://bugu.cntv.cn/live_channelayu/index.shtml Watch live] (SD) }} '''CGTN Arabic''' ({{lang-ar|سي جي تي أن العربية}}), formerly '''CCTV-Arabic''' ({{lang-ar|سي سي تي في العربية}}), is an [[Arabic language]] television channel owned by [[China Global Television Network]], a subsidiary of [[China Central Television]]. [[File:CCTV-A.png|thumb|Former logo of the channel (2009–2016).]] ==Launch== On July 25, 2009, CCTV launched its [[Arabic language|Arabic]]-language international channel, stating that it aims to maintain stronger links with Arabic nations and that the new channel will "serve as an important bridge to strengthen communication and understanding between China and Arab countries".[http://www.cctv.com/program/newshour/20090724/104693.shtml CCTV launches Arabic international channel] - CCTV.com The [[free-to-air]] channel reaches the Middle East and North Africa by Arabsat [[BADR-6]] and [[Nilesat 201]], Europe by [[Eurobird|Eurobird 9]] and Asia-Pacific region by [[Chinasat|Chinasat 6B]]. The channel is also broadcast in traditional and [[High-definition television|high-definition]] format on its official website {{not a typo|arabic}}.cctv.com. CCTV also has plans for a Russian-language channel.[http://news.asiaone.com/News/Latest%2BNews/Showbiz/Story/A1Story20090725-157065.html CCTV launches Arabic channel] - asiaone News The channel is open for view to an audience of potentially 300 million in 22 countries, through the use of satellite television. ==Development and Funding== The ''[[South China Morning Post]]'' reported that CCTV was prepared to spend 45 billion yuan (US$9.5 billion) into the development of the channel, a claim unconfirmed by official sources. ==Content== The channel broadcasts entirely in Arabic, with programs from the four categories of news, feature stories, entertainment and education. Each program is broadcast six times per day, while news reports are regularly updated. The channel will gradually increase the number of programs as it develops. ==See also== * [[CCTV-4|CCTV-4 (International Chinese)]] * [[CCTV International Russian|CCTV-Русский (International Russian)]] * [[CCTV International French|CCTV-Français (International French)]] * [[CCTV International Spanish|CCTV-Español (International Spanish)]] * [[CCTV News (English)|CCTV-NEWS (International English)]] * [[China Network Television (International)|CNTV International]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{official|http://www.cgtn.com/ar.do}} {{ar icon}} * [http://arabic.cntv.cn/20090724/103960.shtml Complete schedule] * [http://arabic.cntv.cn/live/03/index.shtml Live Streaming] * [http://arabic.cntv.cn/live/04/index.shtml Live in HD] {{CCTV}} {{Television in the People's Republic of China}} {{DEFAULTSORT:CCTV International Arabic}} [[Category:China Central Television channels]] [[Category:Television channels and stations established in 2009]] [[Category:Arabic-language television stations]] [[Category:24-hour television news channels in China]] [[Category:2009 establishments in China]] {{PRChina-tv-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2015}} {{Use Indian English|date=September 2015}} {{Infobox TV channel | name = '''DD Chandana''' | logofile =[[File:DD-Chandana-Logo.jpg|155px]] | logosize = | branding = DD Chandana | tag line = | logoalt = | launch = {{start date and age|df=y|1991|8|15}} | owner = Prasar Bharti | country = [[India]] | language = [[Kannada]] ( ಕನ್ನಡ) | headquarters = [[Bengaluru]], [[Karnataka]], [[India]] | available = India | web = http://ddchandana.gov.in |}}
'''DD Chandana''' is a [[Kannada]] TV channel owned and operated by [[Prasar Bharati]] under [[Doordarshan]], supported by Doordarshan studios in [[Bengaluru]] and [[Kalburgi]]. Launched in 1994 DD Chandana has entertainment serials, infotainment programmes, news and current affairs, social programmes and film programmes as its major content. In terrestrial mode, DD Chandana is available to 81.7% of the population of [[Karnataka]].
''Chandana'' in [[Kannada]] means [[sandalwood]].
==History==
A regional language satellite channel was launched on 15 August 1991, which became 24 hrs channel on 1 January 2000. This came to be later on christened as "Chandana",on April 5, 2000 which true to its name has been the true cultural ambassador of the State. It is the Kannada language satellite channel supported by Doordarshan studios in Bengaluru and Kalaburgi. It has entertainment serials, infotainment programmes, news & current affairs, social programmes and film programmes as its major content. In terrestrial mode, DD Chandana is available to 81.7% of the population of Karnataka. Today Doordarshan Bangalore covers an area of 76.2% and population of 82.4%.
DD Chandana has also telecasted programmes on promotion of fire safety at home work place, industry and at community level. Some of the past programs were: Agni Sanchike weekly T.V. serial programme and Fire Warden Organization, to provide an opportunity to volunteers to join hands with the Fire Services in improving fire safety awareness and quick reaction habits in the community. Chandana channel also telecasted 20 commissioned programs, documentaries and software such as drama, telefilms and serials during the year 2004.
==List of programmes== The channel has given the audience a number of memorable programmes of which most popular being * Varthegalu ''(meaning: News)'' - News program * Chitramanjari ''(meaning: Picture snow)'' - Program on Kannada film songs * [[Thatt Antha Heli]] ''(meaning: Answer in a flash)'' - Quiz program * Suththona Namma Nadu ''(meaning: Lets travel our place)'' - A program on Karnataka state travel guide * Kathaa Saritha/Maalike/ ''(meaning: Story garland)'' - A showcase of numerous short stories of [[Kannada literature]] * [[Carnatic Music|Karnataka Shasthreeya Sangeetha]] ''(meaning: Classical music)'' - Musical program * Belagu ''(meaning: Lighten)'' - Interview program of any renowned Guest * Chalanchitra ''(meaning: Movie)''
==Technology==
{{Empty section|date=July 2010}}
== See also== * [[List of programs broadcast by DD National]] * [[All India Radio]] * [[Prasar Bharati|Ministry of Information and Broadcasting]] * [[DD Direct Plus]] * [[List of South Asian television channels by country]]

|postal_code = |area_code_type = [[Telephone numbers in Indonesia|Area code]] |area_code = (+62) 921 |website = {{url|haltimkab.go.id}} |footnotes = }} '''East Halmahera Regency''' ({{lang-id|Kabupaten Halmahera Timur}}) is a [[Regencies of Indonesia|regency]] of [[Halmahera]] in [[North Maluku]] Province, [[Indonesia]]. At the 2010 Census it had a population of 72,880. The capital lies at [[Maba, Indonesia|Maba]], a port on the Gulf of Buli. ==Administration== The regency is divided into ten [[Districts of Indonesia|districts]] (''kecamatan''), tabulated below with their 2010 Census population. {| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! Name || English name || Population
Census 2010 |- | Kota Maba || Maba Town||align="right"|7,508 |- | Maba|| ||align="right"|9,767 |- | Maba Selatan||South Maba||align="right"|6,105 |- | Maba Tengah||Central Maba||align="right"|5,011 |- | Maba Utara||North Maba||align="right"|7,113 |- | Wasile|| ||align="right"|8,915 |- | Wasile Selatan||South Wasile||align="right"|10,999 |- | Wasile Tengah||Central Wasile||align="right"|4,768 |- | Wasile Timur||East Wasile||align="right"|8,676 |- | Wasile Utara||North Wasile||align="right"|4,247 |} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commonscat|East Halmahera Regency}} {{North Maluku}} [[Category:Regencies of North Maluku]] [[Category:Halmahera]] {{Maluku-geo-stub}}

in accordance with [[Help:IPA/Irish]] and [[Help:IPA/Scottish Gaelic]]
revision.text:
<!-- REDIRECT IF MERGED #REDIRECT [[Fáilte Ireland#Etymology]] --> [[Image:Douglas Isle of Man welcome sign.jpg|thumb|250px|right|[[Douglas, Isle of Man]], greets all road users with a [[bilingual]] welcome sign]] [[Image:Failte Scottish.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Scotland likewise welcomes arrivals on the [[A7 road (Great Britain)|A7]], ''Fàilte gu [[Alba]]'' ]] '''Fáilte''' ({{IPA-ga|ˈfˠaːlʲtʲə}}), '''Fàilte''' ({{IPA-gd|ˈfaːltʲə|lang}}), and '''Failt''' ({{IPA-gv|ˈfaːlʲtʃ|lang}}) is a word meaning "welcome".<ref>Ó Dónaill ''Foclóir Gaeilge - Béarla'' (1977, reprint 1992) An Gúm {{ISBN|1-85791-037-0}}</ref>
This word appears in the Irish phrase ''[[wikt:céad míle fáilte|céad míle fáilte]]'' (a hundred thousand welcomes) as well as the similar Scottish phrase ''ceud mìle fàilte'' and the [[Manx Gaelic|Manx]] ''keead milley failt''. It also occurs in the name of [[Fáilte Ireland]] and its predecessor organization, [[Bord Fáilte]] (Board of Welcome). ''[[Fáilte Towers]]'', an [[Radio Telefís Éireann|RTÉ]] [[reality television|reality programme]] broadcast in Ireland in 2008, incorporates this word in its name as well.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.ie/entertainment/tv-radio/faacuteilte-towers-1445331.html|title=Fáilte Towers|date=2008-08-02|accessdate=2008-08-11|publisher=''[[Irish Independent]]''}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.drogheda-independent.ie/entertainment/castlebellingham-to-roll-out-red-carpet-for-reality-tv-stars-1447178.html|title=Castlebellingham to roll out red carpet for reality TV stars|date=2008-08-05|accessdate=2008-08-10|publisher=''[[Drogheda Independent]]''|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080924000045/http://www.drogheda-independent.ie/entertainment/castlebellingham-to-roll-out-red-carpet-for-reality-tv-stars-1447178.html|archivedate=2008-09-24|df=}}</ref>
The accent above the ''a'' is a [[diacritic]] known in [[Irish language|Irish]] as the ''[[síneadh fada]]'' (literally, ''long stretching'', as it lengthens the vowel; often called just the ''fada'' in English), and as the ''stràc'' (pronounced {{IPA-gd|s̪t̪ɾaːxk|}}) in [[Scottish Gaelic]].
==References== {{reflist}}
<!-- DO NOT DELETE THE CATEGORIES after redirecting; they are valid in the redirect -->
{{DEFAULTSORT:Failte}} [[Category:Greeting words and phrases]] [[Category:Irish words and phrases]]
{{Ireland-stub}} {{Scotland-stub}} {{vocab-stub}}

revision.text:
{| class="infobox bordered" style="width: 25em; text-align: left; font-size: 95%;" align=right |+ style="font-size: larger;" | '''Galaxy 26''' |- ! Operator | [[Intelsat]] |- ! Spacecraft Design | [[Space Systems/Loral]] |- ! Orbital location |[[93rd meridian west|93° West]] |- ! Launched from | [[Baikonur Cosmodrome|Baikonur]] LC81 |- ! Launch Date |02-15-1999 |- ! Vehicle |[[LS-1300|FS-1300]] |- ! Design Life |12 years |- ! C-band payload |24 x 36 MHz |- ! Amp type |SSPA, 20 watts |- ! Amp Redundancy |16 for 12 |- ! Receiver redundancy |4 for 2 |- ! Coverage |50 State, Canada, Mexico |- ! Beacon |3700.5 MHz (H) |- ! Beacon |4199.5 MHz (V) |- |}
'''Galaxy 26''' is a [[communications satellite]] owned by [[Intelsat]]. It was built by [[Space Systems/Loral]], as part of its [[LS-1300|FS-1300]] line. Galaxy 26 was formerly known as '''Intelsat Americas 6''' and '''Telstar 6'''. It was launched aboard a [[Proton rocket|Proton-K/DM3]] from [[Baikonur Cosmodrome|Baykonur]] LC81.<ref name = " ">{{cite web | title = Jonathan's Space Report | work = No. 389 | url = http://www.planet4589.org/space/jsr/back/news.389 | accessdate=2007-10-10 }}</ref>
It spent most of its operational life at the [[93rd meridian west|93° W]] [[longitude]] orbital slot, serving the [[North America]]n market. Clients included [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]], [[CBS]], [[CNN]] and [[Fox Broadcasting Company|FOX]].<ref>[http://www.lyngsat.com/galaxy26.html Lyngsat.com list of channels carried on Galaxy 26]</ref>
==The Ailing Bird==
Galaxy 26, known as Telstar 6 at the time, had its share of problems since its February 15, 1999 launch. It had lost a backup command and control receiver, the back up computer, and had completely shut off twice.
The satellite first shut down on April 22, 2001 causing the Fox network to relocate feeds to Telstar 5 at 97° West. Then on April 11, 2002 it shut down again and went into a very slow spin.<ref>http://www.vidiot.com/SatSlates.html</ref>
On June 29, 2008, Galaxy 26 had a power failure in one of its solar panels. It lost 15 kilowatts out of a possible 37 kilowatt capacity, which is very important for charging the batteries.<ref>[http://www.satnews.com/cgi-bin/display_story.cgi?number=264085338 SatNews.com Wattlessness has Afflicted Inteletsat's G26] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716010845/http://www.satnews.com/cgi-bin/display_story.cgi?number=264085338 |date=2011-07-16 }}</ref> Also, there were multiple transponder failures.
Several cable television networks immediately took action to move their feeds to backup satellites in order to keep themselves on air in the event of total failure. Fox News moved operations to Galaxy 16 Transponders 7, 9, and 11, and to AMC 5 Transponder 4K Slot F according to a Fox News internal email. Within a week, CBS had moved all main feeds to Galaxy 25, and all secondary feeds to Galaxy 28, according to an internal email.
In February 2009, following an urgent call from the Pentagon’s Joint staff, Intelsat moved the satellite to the 50.8E orbital position for use by the [[United States Department of Defense]] for [[unmanned aerial vehicle]] support.<ref name="intelsat.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.intelsat.com/news/intelsat-repositions-satellite-to-serve-military-units-in-asia-mideast/ |title=Intelsat Repositions Satellite to Serve Military |work=Intelsat.com |date= 24 March 2009 |accessdate=April 18, 2015}}</ref> This repositioning of the Galaxy-26, which could be reached by U.S. drone operators by using the relay station at [[Ramstein Air Base]], facilitated the rapid expansion of the U.S. drone program.<ref name="theintercept">{{cite web |url=https://firstlook.org/theintercept/2015/04/17/ramstein/ |title=Germany is the Tell-Tale Heart of America's Drone War |work=[[The Intercept]] |date= 2015-04-17 |author=Jeremy Scahill |accessdate= 2015-04-18}}</ref>
==End of Mission==
Galaxy 26 was officially de-orbited on June 7, 2014.<ref>[http://sslmda.com/html/news/galaxy26.html IntelSat Galaxy 26 News.]</ref> The satellite was originally scheduled for de-orbit around March 15, 2014, but that date was extended following delays in the launch of two replacement satellites.<ref>[http://licensing.fcc.gov/myibfs/download.do?attachment_key=1039286 STA Request March 12, 2014]</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Portal|Spaceflight}} * Gunter's Space Page - information on [http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/telstar-5.htm Galaxy 26] *{{satbeams footprint|5279|Galaxy-26 Ku-band North America Beam}} *{{satbeams footprint|5280|Galaxy-26 C-band North America Beam}}
{{Intelsat |state=collapsed}} {{Orbital launches in 1999}}
[[Category:Communications satellites in geostationary orbit]] [[Category:Satellite television]] [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 1999]] [[Category:Satellites using the SSL 1300 bus]]

revision.text:
{{ref improve|date=February 2012}} '''Gerhana Skacinta''' is a [[Malaysia]]n band that specializes in the musical style of [[ska]]. The name is composed of ''gerhana'' 'eclipse', ska, and ''cinta'' 'love'. Although based in a country far from more famous centers of ska culture, the music of the band is not a fusion of Caribbean and Southeast Asian genres, but instead pure, traditional ska style. They are signed to the [[Clockwork Records]] label. The band is influenced by bands such as [[The Skatalites]], [[Lord Kitchener (calypsonian)|Lord Kitchener]] and [[The Wailers (1963-1974 band)|The Wailers]].
==Discography== * ''Tribute to Sweet Charity'' (2001) - A tribute album * ''Skali Skale'' (2002) - A singles alum. * ''Boss Sounds'' (2002) - Their first full album. * ''The New Authentic'' (2004) - Their second full album. * ''This Is Ska'' (2007) - Third Full Album Of GSC * ''Maju Haikal'' (2008) - Full Album Of GSC
==External links== *[https://myspace.com/gerhanaskacinta Gerhana Skacinta] on [[Myspace]]
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gerhana Skacinta}} {{Asia-band-stub}} {{Malaysia-stub}}
[[Category:Malaysian musical groups]] [[Category:Third-wave ska groups]]

page.title: Head of the OCHA Office, Central African Republic

revision.comment: /* List of Heads of the [[OCHA]] Office in [[Central African Republic|CAR]] */AWB general fixes and, delink dates per [[:WP:DATELINK]], [[:WP:YEARLINK]] and [[:MOS:UNLINKYEARS]] using [[Project:AWB|AWB]] (8097)
revision.text:
The '''Head of the [[OCHA]] Office in [[Central African Republic]]''' is the highest post in the tiny African country for the [[United Nations]] [[Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs]], nevertheless a key post in light of the country's current humanitarian emergency.
== List of Heads of the [[OCHA]] Office in [[Central African Republic|CAR]] ==
* [[Souleymane Beye]], May 2005 - December 2006 * Jean-Sebastien Munie, January 2007 - present
[[Category:History of the Central African Republic]] [[Category:United Nations posts]]

{{Infobox Icelandic court |court_name = Labour Court |native_name = Félagsdómur |image = Coat of arms of Iceland.svg |imagesize = 125px |caption = [[Coat of arms of Iceland]] |established = 1938 |dissolved = |country = [[Iceland]] |location = [[Reykjavík]] |coordinates = |composition = 1 appointed by the Confederation of Icelandic Employers

2 appointed by the Supreme Court |authority = Trade Union and Industrial Disputes Act No. 80/1938 |appeal = [[Supreme Court of Iceland|Supreme Court]] |term = 3 years |positions = 5, by statute |budget = |website = {{URL|urskurdir.is}} {{Is icon}} |title = |name = |termstart = |termend = |termend2 = |title2 = |name2 = |termstart2 = |termend3 = |termend4 = }} {{Politics of Iceland}} The '''Labour Court''' ({{Lang-is|Félagsdómur}}) is a special [[lower court]] in [[Iceland]] established in 1938 to handle industrial disputes between [[trade union]]s and [[employer association]]s. ==See also== *[[National Court (Iceland)|National Court]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://urskurdir.is/Felagsmala/Felagsdomur/ Official website] {{Is icon}} {{Courts of Iceland}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Labour Court}} [[Category:1938 establishments in Iceland]] [[Category:Courts in Iceland]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1938]] {{Europe-law-stub}} {{Iceland-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox song contest entry | song = {{flagicon|Croatia}} "Lijepa Tena" | image = [[File:Igor Cukrov - Lijepa Tena.JPG|180px]] | caption = | year = 2009 | country = Croatia | artist = [[Igor Cukrov]] | as = | with = [[Andrea Šušnjara]] | language = Croatian | languages = | composer = [[Tonči Huljić]] | lyricist = Vjekoslava Huljić | place = 18th | points = 45 | place_semi = 13th | points_semi = 33 | lyrics = [http://www.diggiloo.net/?2009hr from Diggiloo Thrush] | prev = Romanca | prev_link = Romanca (Kraljevi ulice & 75 Cents song) | next = Lako je sve | next_link = Lako je sve }} '''"Lijepa Tena"''' (English: ''Beautiful Tena'') is a song by [[Croatia]]n singer [[Igor Cukrov]] and was the Croatian entry to the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2009]], held in [[Moscow]], [[Russia]].{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=1967|title=Igor Cukrov takes the Croatian ticket to Moscow|date=2009-03-01|publisher=''[[European Broadcasting Union|EBU]]''|accessdate=2009-03-01}} The song competed in the second semi-final on 14 May 2009 and qualified for the final, where it finished 18th with 57 points. ==Charts== {| class="wikitable sortable" !align="left"|Chart (2009) !align="left"|Peak
position |- |align="left"|Croatian Top 20 Chart[http://www.hrtop20.info/toplistaarhiva.php?top=ZAB&w=2009/18 Croatian Top 20 Chart] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721205417/http://www.hrtop20.info/toplistaarhiva.php?top=ZAB&w=2009%2F18 |date=July 21, 2011 }} |align="center"|19 |- |} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.diggiloo.net/?2009hr Lyrics] from Diggiloo Thrush {{Eurovision Song Contest 2009}} {{Croatia in Eurovision}} [[Category:Eurovision songs of 2009]] [[Category:Eurovision songs of Croatia]] [[Category:2009 songs]] {{2000s-song-stub}} {{Croatia-stub}}

page.title: National Antarctic Scientific Center of Ukraine

revision.comment: Removed invisible unicode characters + other fixes ([[User:Yobot/55|Task 55]]), replaced: → (3) using [[Project:AWB|AWB]] (12151)
revision.text:
{{Infobox government agency | name = National Antarctic Scientific Center of Ukraine | native_name = Національний антарктичний науковий центр | native_name_a = | native_name_r = | type = [[Government agency]] | seal = | seal_width = | seal_caption = | logo = National Antarctic Scientific Center of Ukraine.svg | logo_width = | logo_caption = | formed = {{Start date and age|1993}} | preceding1 = [[Arctic and Antarctic Research Institute]] (USSR)
| dissolved = | parent_agency = [[Ministry of Education and Science of Ukraine]] | superseding1 = | headquarters = [[Kiev]] }} The '''National Antarctic Scientific Center (NANC)''' ({{lang-uk|Національний антарктичний науковий центр}}, abbreviated as '''НАНЦ''') is an organization of the [[Ukraine|Ukrainian government]], part of the [[Ministry of Education and Science of Ukraine]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.uac.gov.ua/SitePages/Home/Home.aspx|title=НАНЦ - Home|website=www.uac.gov.ua|language=uk-UA|access-date=2018-02-24}}</ref> The Center operates [[Vernadsky Research Base]] and coordinates Ukrainian research of [[Antarctic]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071121013713/http://www.antarctida.kiev.ua/english/|title=Wayback Machine|date=2007-11-21|access-date=2018-02-24}}</ref>
== Goals == The body's goals are:<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.uac.gov.ua/SitePages/ScientificResearch/Scientific_research.aspx|title=НАНЦ - Scientific_research|website=www.uac.gov.ua|language=uk-UA|access-date=2018-02-24}}</ref> * development and implementation of research programs in Antarctica; * ensuring further development of [[Vernadsky Research Base|Vernadsky Research Base;]] * interdisciplinary research in the field of environmental protection.
== Leaders == * Petro Gorzhyk (1996-1999) * Valery Litvinov (1999-2018) * Evgen Diky<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://mon.gov.ua/ua/news/ukrayina-maye-ruhatisya-vglib-antarktiki-takozh-rozvivati-naukovi-doslidzhennya-na-pivnichnomu-polyusi-novij-kerivnik-nanc-yevgen-dikij|title=Міністерство освіти і науки України - Україна має рухатися вглиб Антарктики, а також розвивати наукові дослідження на Північному полюсі – новий керівник НАНЦ Євген Дикий|last=Kitsoft|website=mon.gov.ua|language=ua|access-date=2018-02-24}}</ref>
== Links == * [http://www.uac.gov.ua Official website of the National Antarctic Science Center]
==References== <references /> {{authority control}}
[[Category:Antarctic expeditions]] [[Category:Science and technology in Ukraine]] [[Category:Antarctic agencies]] [[Category:Government agencies of Ukraine]]

page.title: Organization of the Jews in Bulgaria

revision.comment: Moving from [[Category:Religious organisations based in Bulgaria]] to [[Category:Religious organizations based in Bulgaria]] using [[c:Help:Cat-a-lot|Cat-a-lot]]
revision.text:
The '''Organization of the Jews in Bulgaria''' ('''OJB''') coordinates the different [[Judaism|Jewish]] communities in [[Bulgaria]], a country where about 8000 Jews live. This organization organizes programs and projects. The tasks of Shalom – OJB are mainly: *Keeping up and promoting the Jewish values and traditions regarding ethnological, linguistic and cultural aspects *Defending the constitutional rights of its members as well as of all Jews in Bulgaria against the state, its organs and other public and political facilities of the state *Supporting the reduction of racism, [[totalitarianism]], antidemocratical tendencies, fascism, anti-Semitism and national [[chauvinism]] in any kind *Cooperating with any societies and organizations at home and abroad which correlate to the principles of democracy and human rights *Organizing seminars, academic facilities and other training centers *Marketing and popularization of the Jewish values *Promoting education and culture *Organizing concerts, stage plays and book presentations *Building up data archives *Maintaining the historical sites (synagogues, graves, memorials etc.)
==External links== *[http://shalompr.org Organization of the Jews in Bulgaria "Shalom"] *[http://www.gedenkdienst.org Gedenkdienst] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110908140444/http://www.vagabond.bg/jewishbulgaria/ Dimana Trankova, Anthony Georgieff, "Guide to Jewish Bulgaria," Vagabond Media Sofia, 2011]
[[Category:Jews and Judaism in Bulgaria]] [[Category:Religious organizations based in Bulgaria]] [[Category:Holocaust commemoration]]
{{bulgaria-stub}} {{Jewish-org-stub}} {{charity-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox station | name= Schaan-Vaduz | type= [[Railway stations in Liechtenstein|Railway station]] of [[Liechtenstein]] | image=Schaan-Vaduz.jpg | image_size=300px | image_caption= View of the station building | address= Postastrasse 5, [[Schaan]]
{{Flag icon|Liechtenstein}} [[Liechtenstein]] | coordinates={{Coord|47|10|07|N|9|30|30|E|type:railwaystation_region:LI|display=inline,title}} | line= [[Feldkirch–Buchs railway|Feldkirch–Buchs]] | other= | structure=at-grade | platform=1 | depth= | levels= | tracks= 2 | parking= yes | bicycle= | baggage_check= | opened= 1872 | closed= | rebuilt= | electrified= yes | ADA= | code= | owned= [[Austrian Federal Railways|ÖBB]] | zone= | former= | passengers= | pass_year= | pass_percent= | pass_system= | mpassengers= | services= | map_locator= [[File:Rail map of Liechtenstein.PNG|200px|A map of Liechtenstein showing the railway line and the 4 stations]] | map_status = collapsed }} '''Schaan-Vaduz''' is one of the 4 [[train station]]s serving [[Liechtenstein]], located in the town of [[Schaan]], 3.5 km from [[Vaduz]]. It is owned by the [[Austrian Federal Railways]] (ÖBB). == Overview == Schaan-Vaduz is situated on the international and electrified [[Feldkirch–Buchs Railway|Feldkirch-Buchs]] line,Linking [[Austria]] and [[Switzerland]] between the station of [[Buchs railway staion|Buchs]] (in [[Switzerland]]) and the stop of [[Forst Hilti railway station|Forst Hilti]] (in the northern suburb of Schaan). It is served only by regional trains. Located in the middle of town, the station is composed of a two-storey building, a wooden shed and a platform serving the first [[Track (rail transport)|track]]. The second track has no platform and is rarely used.{{de icon}} [http://www.bahnbilder.de/name/einzelbild/number/279809/kategorie/Liechtenstein~Bahnh%F6fe~Schaan-Vaduz.html Picture of the tracks with a brief description] Located on the platform is the rements of a rail line, part of a dismantled track system used by [[Goods wagon|freight wagons]].{{de icon}} [http://www.bahnbilder.de/name/einzelbild/number/305585/kategorie/Liechtenstein~Bahnh%F6fe~Schaan-Vaduz.html Picture of the station platform with a brief description] {{s-start|noclear=yes}} {{s-rail|title=ÖBB}} {{rail line |previous=[[Buchs railway station|Buchs SG]]|next=[[Forst Hilti railway station|Schaan Forst Hilti]]|route=[[Austrian Federal Railways|ÖBB]]
[[Feldkirch–Buchs railway]]|col=FF0000}} {{end}} == Gallery == File:Bahnhof Schaan-Vaduz 20-08-2007.JPG|A [[Motafonerbahn]] train in Schaan-Vaduz File:ÖBB Bahnhof Schaan-Vaduz.jpg|Platform side. In background, the [[Goods station|goods depot]] == See also == * [[Forst Hilti railway station]] * [[Nendeln railway station]] * [[Schaanwald railway station]] * [[Rail transport in Liechtenstein]] * [[Railway stations in Liechtenstein]] == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == {{commons category|Bahnhof Schaan-Vaduz|Schaan-Vaduz railway station}} *{{de icon}} [http://www.bahnbilder.de/name/galerie/kategorie/Liechtenstein~Bahnh%F6fe~Schaan-Vaduz.html Schaan-Vaduz page on www.bahnbilder.de] {{Rail transport in Liechtenstein}} [[Category:Railway stations in Liechtenstein]] [[Category:Railway stations opened in 1872]] [[Category:Schaan|Railway Station]] [[Category:Vaduz]] {{Liechtenstein-stub}}

revision.text:
{{primary sources|date=October 2011}} The '''World Rainforest Movement''' (WRM) is an international [[NGO]] and Indigenous Peoples' Groups network involved in efforts to defend the world's tropical forests against the forces that destroy them.
Since its creation in 1986, WRM has played an important role as catalyst and critic and has particularly championed the rights of forest-dwelling communities. The idea was to link peoples’ organisations and movements working on forest related policies and projects of the [[World Bank]] and other [[International Financial Institutions]] (IFIs) with the aim of countering the influence of the timber industry.
The secretarial of the World Rainforest Movement is based in Montevideo, Uruguay, while its European support office is based in and hosted by [[FERN]] and [[Forest Peoples Programme]] in [[Moreton-in-Marsh]], [[United Kingdom]].
==See also== * [[SinksWatch]]
==External links== * [http://www.wrm.org.uy/ WRM]
[[Category:Environmental organizations based in Uruguay]] [[Category:Indigenous rights organizations]] [[Category:International forestry organizations]] [[Category:Tropical rainforests]] [[Category:International environmental organizations]]

revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox broadcast | call_letters = ZBM-TV| station_logo = ZBMNews9.png | station_slogan = | station_branding = ZBM TV 9 (general)
ZBM 9 News (newscasts)| digital = 20 ([[Ultra high frequency|UHF]])| virtual = 20.1 ([[PSIP]])| other_chs = | affiliations = [[CBS]]| founded = 1958| location = [[Hamilton, Bermuda]]| callsign_meaning = '''Z''' '''B'''er'''M'''uda| former_callsigns = | former_channel_numbers = [[Analog television|Analog]]: 9 ([[Very high frequency|VHF]])|| owner = [[Bermuda Broadcasting|Bermuda Broadcasting Company]]| sister_stations = [[ZFB-TV]]| former_affiliations = | effective_radiated_power = | HAAT = | class = | facility_id = | homepage = | }} '''ZBM-TV''' is a television station serving [[Hamilton, Bermuda|Hamilton]] and the [[United Kingdom|British]] territory of [[Bermuda]]. It is owned by [[Bermuda Broadcasting|Bermuda Broadcasting Company]] and is an affiliate of [[United States]] [[television network]] [[CBS]]. The station broadcasts over-the-air on [[NTSC|analog]] channel 9 and is carried on channel 3 on the local cable television system. ==History== '''ZBM-TV''' was founded in 1958 by Bermuda Broadcasting Company as the first local television station in Bermuda. Before then, residents living near [[Kindley Air Force Base|Kindley Field]] at the East End of Bermuda could watch television via unauthorized reception of the TV signal on base. An affiliation with CBS was added in 1960. The station transitioned to color in 1968, possibly the first color television service on the island of Bermuda. Originally, ZBM-TV broadcast on channel 10, but in 1974, Capital Broadcasting Company merged with Bermuda Broadcasting Company and ZBM-TV was moved to channel 9. ==Digital television== On the week of March 9, 2016, ZBM-TV and sister ZFB-TV shut off their analog transmitters and converted to [[digital television]] broadcasts on UHF 20. Unlike other [[digital terrestrial television]] broadcasters in North America (which have switched to [[ATSC]], Bermuda uses [[DVB-T]] for its digital television system.http://bernews.com/2016/03/dd-bermuda-broadcasting-moving-digital-tv-output/ ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://zbmnews9.wordpress.com/category/lets-talk/ ZBM-9 Official site] *[http://www.bermuda-online.org/media.htm Bermuda News media] {{Bermuda TV}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Zbm-Tv}} [[Category:Television stations in Bermuda]] [[Category:CBS network affiliates]] [[Category:Television channels and stations established in 1958]] [[Category:Transnational network affiliates]] {{UK-tv-channel-stub}} {{Bermuda-stub}}
